Situation1: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Expectation2: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation2: A weekly study slot is planned, and lessons could be shifted without losing continuity.
Story: The line at the register snakes around the bakery, everyone impatient, the air thick with the scent of cinnamon and stress. I force a smile as the next customer slams a loaf of challah on the counter, voice sharp, demanding to know why the wait is so long. My manager’s eyes flick to me, silently urging patience and cheerfulness. I nod, swallowing my own frustration, and try to soothe the customer, apologizing and promising to be quick. But my phone buzzes in my pocket—a reminder that I’m supposed to be home soon, leading my kids in our weekly study of Jewish history. I picture their eager faces, the books spread out, the stories waiting to be told. I know I could shift the lesson, but I promised them this time together, to pass on our traditions. The demands of my job and my faith pull at me, each expecting my full attention, and I feel the tension knotting in my chest as I ring up the next order, caught between the world behind the counter and the one waiting at home.
